body.p:
When I last wrote you I had not yet received
our note of 31st October sent with the Occidents. It is to this that I
would now reply. As I before wrote you I shall always be most ready
and happy to do anything that my poor ability will permit so as to
serve you, but even now I know not what to do. You have authorised
me to receipt for you, Mr Joseph is your agent for the Occident, and
as I believe, nay am sure, does the needful there, A couple of subscribers
have not paid their dues for the A of P. Mr J. says you ought to send
bills. Knowing the amounts however I shall try & collect for you, I
certainly will endeavor to do my best to get you new subscribers but I
think that conservatively? there are no more religious readers here than
in other Hebrew—with respect to the convention of which you speak
more fully in your last I have to remark that nothing would give
me quater? pleasure than participating in a movement which
might (and doubtless would) tend to promote the awfully neglected
subjects of our much prized faith. Anything that will agitate, arouse
our community from the Hebrew which now enwraps and paralyses
them, should be encouraged by every lover of Gods people. My pen
as if in spite of me runs on transcribing the declaration of the wise king Hebrew
But though my wishes would be with the project I fear I could
but little promote it. Nevertheless I am prepared to take part
in it, to do myself me the pleasure of taking a trip to New York
and to make the acquaintance personally with Messrs Wise ? Thus you
see dear Friend I I not only approve the plan if this were of any ?
I am prepared to extend to at my best support. God grant
that the movement (should it indeed take place) may prove an
important one, and beneficial to this and other generations “yet unborn”

I do not know that I should have any influence in creating in Mr Lyons
a willingness to join us. I have to write to congratulate him on the
birth of his son, and shall then urge the matter, and invite his
favorable consideration. What says Messrs Isaacs Leo & Lilienthall what
Mr gutheim and other Hazanim, Let me know on response.

When I can look over and finish it I will send you an
translation of a chapter I made just before leaving England from Peutrol's well known Hebrew
I have furnished it with rather long notes to defend him and other
Hebrew authors from the attacks of Batnaye and others, the
subject matter of this chapter relates to the history of R David
? the supposed ambassador from the Ten Tribes more subtly related in the Hebrew, will it
suit the Occident, a Defence (such as it is) of any portion of
our Hebrew writers I should say ought not to be considered (by the
public) as out of place there! If I do not hear from you
before it is finished (I am rather busy now) I shall send
it you—Hebrew—

You acted as agent for the Voice of Jacob. Would it be
too much to ask of you to forward me per opportunity the
numbers ? below. I have on order from Dr Beuisth
and assert from Mr Difman to receive them “either...? money
or without price, perhaps you dont know I made great
efforts for the contrivance of the paper. When Franklin
finally retired, and that I was co-editor of the 1st two
or three nos of the new series. He wanted me much to
undertake it with Dr B. but I left England for Montreal.
I wanted nevertheless the conservative paper such as it
was, to continue. I may then at? for new numbers
Pray don't be so long before you write, let

me hear how our projected convention gets on, and let's have all the
Hebrew you can scrape together How gets on our friend Bernal?
I wrote him some 9 months ago but Hebrew—I hope
he is well in health and better in circumstances then when he
last wrote. If you see him please tell him I shall be
glad to hear from him and am surprised that I have
not yet received a line from him. He does not appear to
be so fond of writing now as when in Montego Bay

Hoping that you also are in good health and
“kicking” I am Dear Friend

By the way, I hear you were lately
in New York, hence you had a good
opportunity to speak to Mr Lyons & others, Did you so

The following are the nos of the voice with
which you will please furnish me.

43.48.50.52.53.54.55. from 57 inclusive to 72 from 73 incl
to 87.90.93.94.101.105.106.113 new series vol 1. nos
20 & 25. and of the last vol (vol 7) 2.4.5.6.11.12.14.16.17.
22. and 24 to the end. I ask you to supply me for the
sake of dispatch let me know therefore at once whether
you can let me have them, if you cant I will write at
once to my uncle who printed them. that will take some
months before I can get them in this way.
